articles.headline: A System Overdue for Reform
articles.snippet: A growing and diverse number of experts agree that the financial system needs an overhaul.
articles.abstract: A growing and diverse number of experts agree that the financial system needs an overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week ago Thursday, just days after the big Bear Stearns crisis, Representative Barney Frank gave a speech to the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce. Most people know Mr. Frank, a Democrat from Massachusetts, as one of the most liberal members of Congress.

articles.headline: Barry Diller Wins as Court Allows His 5-Way Division of IAC
articles.snippet: A Delaware court ruled in favor of IAC/InterActiveCorp’s Barry Diller in his dispute with Liberty Media’s chairman John Malone, paving the way for IAC to proceed with its planned spin-off of four units.
articles.abstract: A Delaware court ruled in favor of IAC/InterActiveCorp’s Barry Diller in his dispute with Liberty Media’s chairman John Malone, paving the way for IAC to proceed with its planned spin-off of four units.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the battle of the billionaire media moguls, the protégé won.

articles.headline: Trying to Get the Swiss to Talk
articles.snippet: A tax-evasion scandal in Germany has sparked a debate in Switzerland about the country’s banking secrecy.
articles.abstract: A tax-evasion scandal in Germany has sparked a debate in Switzerland about the country’s banking secrecy.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA  Like Paul Revere, Konrad Hummler sounded the alarm last week as he made his way by train and by plane to his bank’s branches across Switzerland. This country’s storied role as secret banker to the world’s wealthy is under threat like never before, Mr. Hummler warned.

articles.headline: U.S. Airstrikes Aid Iraqi Army in Basra
articles.snippet: Iraqi forces, which have no air support of their own, have so far failed to subdue Shiite militias in Basra and have asked the Americans and British for help.
articles.abstract: Iraqi forces, which have no air support of their own, have so far failed to subdue Shiite militias in Basra and have asked the Americans and British for help.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The American military conducted airstrikes Thursday and Friday to back up stalled Iraqi forces in Basra and battle Shiite militias in Baghdad as continued violence and political infighting worsened the prospects for any timely reconciliation among Iraq’s warring factions.

articles.headline: First, Self-Control. Then, Debt Control.
articles.snippet: While the financial experts are urging people to pay down debt — particularly expensive credit card debt — that is easier said than done.
articles.abstract: While the financial experts are urging people to pay down debt — particularly expensive credit card debt — that is easier said than done.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you have gotten in over your head in credit card debt, you are in good company. The Federal Reserve says Americans have accumulated nearly $1 trillion, a record amount, in what it calls “revolving credit.”

articles.headline: Endorsement of Obama Points Up Clinton Obstacles
articles.snippet: An endorsement of Senator Barack Obama by Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania underlined the ferment in the Democratic race.
articles.abstract: An endorsement of Senator Barack Obama by Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania underlined the ferment in the Democratic race.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Adam Nagourney, Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny and written by Mr. Nagourney.

articles.headline: Treasury’s Plan Would Give Fed Wide New Power
articles.snippet: A plan would give the Federal Reserve broad new authority to oversee financial market stability.
articles.abstract: A plan would give the Federal Reserve broad new authority to oversee financial market stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department will propose on Monday that Congress give the Federal Reserve broad new authority to oversee financial market stability, in effect allowing it to send SWAT teams into any corner of the industry or any institution that might pose a risk to the overall system.

articles.headline: Growing Gulf Divides China and Old Foe
articles.snippet: A gap between Western and Chinese leaders on perceptions of the Dalai Lama is breeding pessimism that China will take a new approach to Tibet.
articles.abstract: A gap between Western and Chinese leaders on perceptions of the Dalai Lama is breeding pessimism that China will take a new approach to Tibet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Across much of the Western world, the Dalai Lama is known as the beatific spiritual leader of a humble community of Buddhists, beloved in Hollywood, Congress and the White House, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.

articles.headline: High Rice Cost Creating Fears of Asia Unrest
articles.snippet: The price of rice, a staple in the diets of nearly half the world’s population, has almost doubled on international markets.
articles.abstract: The price of rice, a staple in the diets of nearly half the world’s population, has almost doubled on international markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANOI  Rising prices and a growing fear of scarcity have prompted some of the world’s largest rice producers to announce drastic limits on the amount of rice they export.

articles.headline: Penney’s Warning Adds to Retail Gloom
articles.snippet: J. C. Penney sharply cut its earnings forecast for the first three months of the year, blaming the tough economy in yet another sign of distress in American retailing.
articles.abstract: J. C. Penney sharply cut its earnings forecast for the first three months of the year, blaming the tough economy in yet another sign of distress in American retailing.
articles.lead_paragraph: For retailers, doing everything right is no longer enough.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: If You Can’t Sell, Good Luck
articles.snippet: A market dries up, and the little guy is left holding the debt.
articles.abstract: A market dries up, and the little guy is left holding the debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHERE’S my bailout?

articles.headline: Foreclosure Machine Thrives on Woes
articles.snippet: Law firms and default servicing companies have been raking in mounting profits on foreclosures.
articles.abstract: Law firms and default servicing companies have been raking in mounting profits on foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOBODY wins when a home enters foreclosure  neither the borrower, who is evicted, nor the lender, who takes a loss when the home is resold. That’s the conventional wisdom, anyway.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Shiite Militias Cling to Swaths of Basra and Stage Raids
articles.snippet: Militias openly controlled many areas of the city as Iraqi political leaders grew increasingly critical of the stalled assault.
articles.abstract: Militias openly controlled many areas of the city as Iraqi political leaders grew increasingly critical of the stalled assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Shiite militiamen in Basra openly controlled wide swaths of the city on Saturday and staged increasingly bold raids on Iraqi government forces sent five days ago to wrest control from the gunmen, witnesses said, as Iraqi political leaders grew increasingly critical of the stalled assault.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Michael Kamber

articles.headline: Files Suggest Venezuela Bid to Aid Colombia Rebels
articles.snippet: If verified, the files would offer rare insight into Latin America’s longest-running guerrilla conflict.
articles.abstract: If verified, the files would offer rare insight into Latin America’s longest-running guerrilla conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia  Files provided by Colombian officials from computers they say were captured in a cross-border raid in Ecuador this month appear to tie Venezuela’s government to efforts to secure arms for Colombia’s largest insurgency.

articles.headline: An Oilman Entices, and Investors Cry Foul
articles.snippet: With oil prices topping $100 a barrel, con artists are eager to lure investors into suspect deals. State regulators say their powers to shut these schemes down are limited.
articles.abstract: With oil prices topping $100 a barrel, con artists are eager to lure investors into suspect deals. State regulators say their powers to shut these schemes down are limited.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIKE so many of the over-the-top birthday parties that typically appear on “My Super Sweet 16” on MTV, Ariel’s celebration took the fairy-tale-princess theme to new heights.

articles.headline: Iraqi Offensive Revives Debate for Campaigns
articles.snippet: The war’s return to the public consciousness poses new challenges and opportunities for the candidates, particularly Senator John McCain.
articles.abstract: The war’s return to the public consciousness poses new challenges and opportunities for the candidates, particularly Senator John McCain.
articles.lead_paragraph: The heavy fighting that broke out last week as Iraqi security forces tried to oust Shiite militias from Basra is reverberating on the presidential campaign trail and posing new challenges and opportunities to the candidates, particularly Senator John McCain.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Larry Rohter

articles.headline: In Treasury Plan, a Reluctant Eye Over Wall Street
articles.snippet: A plan for the biggest change in financial regulation since the 1930s was born in an effort to limit Washington’s role.
articles.abstract: A plan for the biggest change in financial regulation since the 1930s was born in an effort to limit Washington’s role.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration is proposing the broadest overhaul of Wall Street regulation since the Great Depression. But the plan, to be unveiled on Monday, has its genesis in a yearlong effort to limit Washington’s role in the market.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Floyd Norris

articles.headline: McCain Faces Test in Wooing Elite Donors
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain has so far managed to enlist only a fraction of the heavyweight fund-raisers who helped drive President Bush’s two runs for the White House.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain has so far managed to enlist only a fraction of the heavyweight fund-raisers who helped drive President Bush’s two runs for the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: With attention focused on the Democrats’ infighting for the presidential nomination, Senator John McCain is pressing ahead to the general election but has yet to sign up one critical constituency: the big-money people who powered the Bush fund-raising machine.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Griff Palmer

articles.headline: Citizen Huff
articles.snippet: Since the blog The Huffington Post was launched, it has grown in ways that few people, except perhaps its co-founder, Arianna Huffington, expected.
articles.abstract: Since the blog The Huffington Post was launched, it has grown in ways that few people, except perhaps its co-founder, Arianna Huffington, expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Ari Emanuel called me last night with an idea for a blog,” Arianna Huffington said last week as she sipped an iced coffee in the New York offices of The Huffington Post.

articles.headline: Tracking a Marine Lost at Home
articles.snippet: A search for a missing Iraq veteran drives home a hard truth: wars do not always end when warriors return.
articles.abstract: A search for a missing Iraq veteran drives home a hard truth: wars do not always end when warriors return.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  A week after Eric W. Hall disappeared into the woods of Southwest Florida, his mother stood in a parking lot overlooking the Gulf of Mexico. She had asked for volunteers. Would they come?

articles.headline: Chinese Nationalism Fuels Tibet Crackdown
articles.snippet: If the tough tactics have startled the outside world, the Communist Party for now seems more concerned with rallying domestic opinion.
articles.abstract: If the tough tactics have startled the outside world, the Communist Party for now seems more concerned with rallying domestic opinion.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Like so many Chinese, Meng Huizhong was horrified by the violent Tibetan protests in Lhasa. She cringed at videos of Tibetan rioters attacking a Chinese motorcyclist. Her anger deepened as Tibet dominated her online conversation groups, until it settled on what might seem like an unlikely target: the Communist Party.

articles.headline: We Want It, and Waiting Is No Option
articles.snippet: The Web empowers both groups and individuals as a place where choice is not only an option, but an imperative.
articles.abstract: The Web empowers both groups and individuals as a place where choice is not only an option, but an imperative.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Virgin Megastore in Times Square was bustling last Thursday during the lunch hour, but with two remarkably different universes of consumers. One group of shoppers  none of whom appeared to be under 40  were browsing manually through CDs, no doubt some of them drawn by Virgin’s profit-killing $10 price.

articles.headline: Online Chat, as Inspired by Real Chat
articles.snippet: A new wave of Silicon Valley companies is bringing live socializing into online social networking Web sites.
articles.abstract: A new wave of Silicon Valley companies is bringing live socializing into online social networking Web sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Compared with other forms of human interaction, online social networking is really not all that social.

articles.headline: As Jobs Vanish and Prices Rise, Food Stamp Use Nears Record
articles.snippet: The number of Americans receiving food stamps is projected to reach 28 million in the coming year.
articles.abstract: The number of Americans receiving food stamps is projected to reach 28 million in the coming year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Driven by a painful mix of layoffs and rising food and fuel prices, the number of Americans receiving food stamps is projected to reach 28 million in the coming year, the highest level since the aid program began in the 1960s.

articles.headline: Cleric Suspends Battle in Basra by Shiite Militia
articles.snippet: The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr called for his followers to stop fighting and demanded concessions from Iraq’s government.
articles.abstract: The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr called for his followers to stop fighting and demanded concessions from Iraq’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on Sunday called for his followers to stop fighting in Basra and in turn demanded concessions from Iraq’s government, after six days in which his Mahdi Army militia has held off an American-supported Iraqi assault on the southern port city.
articles.byline: By Erica Goode and James Glanz

articles.headline: A Nervous Wall St. Seems Unsure What’s Next
articles.snippet: Most everyone wants to know when the financial crisis will end. So far the markets are whispering an answer that no one wants to hear.
articles.abstract: Most everyone wants to know when the financial crisis will end. So far the markets are whispering an answer that no one wants to hear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most everyone on Wall Street, and on Main Street, wants to know when will the financial crisis end. So far, despite the government’s efforts, the markets are whispering an answer that no one wants to hear.

articles.headline: Who Are We? New Dialogue on Mixed Race
articles.snippet: Many multiracial Americans say Barack Obama’s speech about race rang with a special significance in their ears.
articles.abstract: Many multiracial Americans say Barack Obama’s speech about race rang with a special significance in their ears.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jenifer Bratter once wore a T-shirt in college that read “100 percent black woman.” Her African-American friends would not have it.
